Always had a soft spot for this one. Tried playing it at launch back in '16 but had to shelve it owing to the flashy 14 fps I got out of it with my laptop. To this day it struggles to run at 60 locked. Underrated? Maybe. Could it have reached the status Cyberpunk has if the devs locked in and addressed all the glitches and the severe lack of polish? Not quite since Mafia 3 has a repetition problem.   Mafia 3 is severely repetitive with its mission design but I don't think it's as soul-lessly repetitive as something like ubisoft's latest installments. 
These Racket missions all have you running around and causing a specified amount of damage/loss to take down the businesses. It being grindy and repetitive is an understatement but the thing is a lot of the level design seem distinct enough, the set pieces all look pretty unique from eachother most of the time and the shooting mechanics is crisp af with stealth being viable as well, so ultimately, the pacing of the narrative throughout these missions is what made it a slog to get through for the better part of the game. I found it extremely annoying when the game forces you to revisit the same locations you‚Äôd already been to earlier just to kill or recruit one of the racket bosses. They shouldn't have opted the ubislop route of not just having a kill list but also making it grindy af to the likes of something like Wildlands or Odyssey. It might be a better experience to play the game slowly and avoid the repetitiveness get to you, but it's a Mafia game, you play it solely for the narrative.
Rockstar has the same tedious mission design of moving from A to B to kill someone. But what makes their games stand out is that the focus on narrative is never lost, they keep expanding and developing on their characters and plot, so it makes these repetitive ass missions playable to a great degree which is something that Mafia 3 forgets to do. And the thing with M3 is that you know where the plot is heading towards right at the start of it all, so it has no reason to stretch itself like it did, there was no gotcha moment at the end, Lincoln accomplishes exactly what he sets out to do and his character barely changes during it. Now the execution of Sal and Giorgi's ending was amazing but not sure if it was worth all the grindy parts of it preceding that. All the character bio was so nicely written, just hope they had infused all that into the story in the form of cutscenes/driving conversations. I say this as someone who loves third person shooters the most out of all genres, TPS has gotten stale and monotonous, so you need to make it linear and have a neat narrative tied along with it. There's a reason why no one else attempts to do a full fledged open world TPS other than rockstar nowadays. So yeah it was a poor decision on hangar 13's part to bury a decent story under all that repetitiveness when they could have gone the same route as the previous games or paced the story well to fit the open world. I like how you get benefits out of all the racketeering that are actually pretty helpful when it comes to gameplay. Really wish they hadn't abandoned some of the mechanics introduced here in Mafia Old Country. The driving felt really good but the pedestrians resembled those from GTA 3 where they dive into the car to kill themselves instead of just walking like a normal human being üò≠. Also I found the driving to be disgusting when I first picked it up but that was all because of the performance. And to think of it narratively it makes absolutely no sense why THREE underbosses would uselessly and shamelessly depend on a single guy to toss all the districts and rackets to them and be ungrateful pricks about it. Speaking of it, I really hoped Vito would have had a bigger presence in the story instead of being one of these obnoxious underbosses I mentioned. Also I don't think they should've teased Joe like that in the ending, kinda removes the impact and ambiguity of the 2nd game's ending. Overall the endings were neat tho some where outright hilarious like the one where father james randomly plants a bomb under Lincoln's car. M3 had it all,  be it the amazing driving mechanics, satisfying gunplay, a stellar soundtrack or a captivating premise but it all gets buried under a grindy mission design and a few game breaking glitches here and there. Might check out the dlcs soon enough.

If you‚Äôve made it this far, my sincerest of apologies to all the non-existent readers for my repetitive use of the word ‚Äúrepetitive.‚Äù üôèüèº

Pros
- Visceral combat. Both you and enemies go down fast, making for some intense gunplay, kills aren't always clean too, with enemies lying wounded, begging for their lives or groaning, emphasising the brutality, though for you you do get adrenaline shots you can use to recover from near-death and buff your health back, but that only goes a little towards making you less squishy until you get late game upgrades for it.
- Memorable setting and story. A Southern US city with French influence, diverse range of gangs (Hillbillies, KKK, Mafiosi, Haitians, Irish), and easily hateable racist scumbags trying to hold back the march of the civil rights era, and a narrative told in several formats, the 60s, which acts as your character's present, and flashforwards in some cutscenes to 2 different forms, a 1970s Senate hearing and a 2010s documentary, speaking about your crime spree in past tense with the characters reflecting on it, those characters are certainly interesting too, both friends and enemies, well voice acted with excellently mocapped cutscenes. Plus the radio music rules.
- Sit Down system. Mafia 3 is all about conquering the city, the basic gameplay loop is this, you have 9 districts to take over by killing their bosses, each district has its boss (representing the whole district) and 2 underlings (representing its 2 rackets/businesses), the first 3 districts are automatically assigned to your 3 different ally gangs, but after that you get to decide who gets what, earning cash and unique perks from the allies you provide for, each offering 4 district‚Äôs worth of perks and 3 district's worth of loyalty missions which add a little extra story at the end of the chain. First you can decide rackets individually, but once you kill the boss you assign the district as a whole, giving all of its rackets to your chosen ally. Each ally always wants the turf, but their hunger for it will be impacted by 2 things, whether you already gave them rackets in that turf, and their overall loyalty (based on if you give them turfs previously, or did post-turf loyalty missions for them), you can keep them all happy and make lots of cash together if you play your cards right, but if you don't they'll ditch you and become a problem to be dealt with and a hole in your wallet. The only real flaw it has is there‚Äôs no real reason to assign any rackets to a boss you don‚Äôt plan to give the turf to, as it just pisses them off with no benefits, making that choice basically irrelevant.
- Quality DLCs. The DLC missions, included free in this edition, are great fun with proper plotlines and unique missions, best played in between waves of district conquering to break up their monotony.
- Smoother controls driving. Taking an even further step in this direction from M2 the driving is fast and it‚Äôs easy to make turns, making for really nice cruising round the city that only really is lost if you pick a really shit vehicle or it gets so shot to bits you don‚Äôt have any tires left to cruise with. On foot it‚Äôs easier to snap in and out of cover too.

Cons
- Repetitive gameplay loop. To draw out a district boss you have to kill their underlings and to draw out the underlings you have to meddle with their rackets, you do that by doing assassinations, interrogations (just a takedown where you hold instead of press the button), thefts, property destruction and the occasional hostage rescue, these get very repetitive very fast. That gets added to once districts are taken over, where you have delivery jobs to do to increase their income and the loyalty missions (which include more collectathons and assassination jobs), although those are at least optional. These generic, repetitive, plot lite, bite sized jobs make up the vast majority of missions, with only the Prologue, District Bosses*, Finale and DLC content including unique encounters.
- Wonky takedown system. Takedowns can either be lethal or non lethal, but rather than being 2 different keybinds or a press/hold distinction, lethality has to be toggled in the options menu, underling bosses can also only be spared if you do the arbitrary extra step of wiretapping their area, otherwise Lincoln will automatically kill them.
- Occasional tanky enemies. In general combat is fast paced, but some enemies have artificially buffed health, being able to take dozens of Tommy Gun rounds to the chest with nothing but a generic shirt on and still turn round and blast you as you reload, not fun. This becomes a non issue around half way through the game, when upgrades to your health restoring Adrenaline make you the tanky one.
- Lacking interactivity. Except for car shops all of the game's stores can't be bought from, with resources instead handled through mobile dealers you can call, although those dealers make for great convenience the lack of stores, makes the city feel pretty barren of things to do. You just have the car dealerships, mission content, planting wiretaps and robbery, a step down from M2.
- Mission bugs. Sometimes missions don't appear when they're supposed to, forcing a restart to get them to appear, and sometimes icons for them can show up on the map when they're not actually available, leading you towards red herrings.
- Lacking faction variety. The early game gives the impression you‚Äôll be up against a variety of factions, introducing the Haitians and Dixie Mafia as early rivals, but in reality almost the whole game has you fighting against the Mafia, with the Haitians joining you and Dixie only appearing in filler missions after the prologue. Though you do face the KKK styled Southern Union in select other encounters.
- Loss of collectivity. In M1 you were part of a gang, very frequently working with other mobsters like Paulie and Sam as well as regular goons, in 2 you swapped from family to family but were constantly with your buddy Joe and sometimes others like Henry and Tony, in 3 there‚Äôs almost none of that except for the prologue, where you work with several allies to rob the Federal Reserve. After that Lincoln has people in a support role like the 3 allied gang bosses and their associates, plus his spook ally Donovan, but the actual dirty work is done by him on his own, even though it‚Äôs his crime family. His own gang he was part of before, the Black Mob, is also completely forgotten about after the prologue. A nearly entirely one man war, Rambo style, is a departure from the series that just makes the immersion harder to maintain.
- Simplified police system. Cops don‚Äôt try to arrest you anymore, they either ignore your shit or shoot, and they don‚Äôt enforce most traffic laws unlike M1 and 2 where they‚Äôd try to fine or arrest you for speeding or running red lights, I don‚Äôt mind not being harassed by that given how much driving there is to do, but the option would be cool, especially for this setting where these racist cops would pull you over for any little thing irl, they also don't remember you/your vehicle‚Äôs look after being wanted.
- Outfit choice not respected. Because most cutscenes are pre-rendered, Lincoln will always appear in cutscenes in his veteran jacket, rather than what you chose to wear.

*District Bosses are usually 1 mission, but the last set of bosses have 2 missions, having you take down an accomplice of theirs too

For much of my first 9 hours with the game (where I conquered the first 3 districts) I really hated it, drained by its constant repetition, but after playing one of the DLCs, getting a breather, when I came back to the main game I found I wasn‚Äôt bothered as much, since the combat and driving is a solid core, in the end enjoying the game despite its faults, especially since more weapon and vehicle unlocks sped up those repetitive rackets, letting me get to the more substantial parts faster.

The fact that they barely bothered to include proper missions really keeps it down, leaving it as just good, rather than truly great, but on balance, I‚Äôd say it's worth a play.

6/10 ‚Äì Ambitious but Flawed Entry in the Mafia Series

Mafia III: Definitive Edition is a bold departure from the classic Mafia formula, offering strong storytelling and a powerful setting, but ultimately falling short of the high standards set by Mafia and Mafia II. While the game delivers emotional weight and compelling themes, its repetitive gameplay and technical issues prevent it from reaching its full potential.

Set in the beautifully realized 1968 city of New Bordeaux, the game introduces a fresh protagonist‚ÄîLincoln Clay, a Vietnam veteran seeking revenge after the brutal destruction of his adopted family. The story is gritty, mature, and told with an impressive documentary-style structure. The voice acting and cinematic presentation are some of the best in the series, and the soundtrack perfectly captures the era with legendary tracks from the late ‚Äô60s rock and soul scene.

However, compared to previous Mafia titles, the gameplay loop becomes predictable quickly. Missions follow a repetitive structure of clearing districts, destroying rackets, and confronting lieutenants‚Äîlacking the tight pacing and memorable set pieces of Mafia: Definitive Edition or Mafia II. While the gunplay and driving are solid, the world often feels large but empty, missing the intentional, story-driven design that made earlier games so special.

Comparing with earlier Mafia games:

Mafia: Definitive Edition delivers a tightly crafted, emotional narrative with classic gangster atmosphere.

Mafia II: Definitive Edition combines cinematic storytelling and unforgettable characters with a richly immersive setting.

Mafia III: Definitive Edition reaches high narrative ambition but sacrifices gameplay depth and pacing, leading to a less cohesive experience.

Despite flaws, Mafia III deserves credit for exploring deeper themes like racism, trauma, and loyalty with maturity and intensity rarely seen in the genre. But the repetitive mission structure and technical issues hold it back from greatness.

A powerful story trapped inside an uneven game.

While the narrative does deviate from the original Mafia and Mafia II, this game very much holds its own in the trilogy. It has the most complex narrative of all the games. It is a revenge story against the mob, but it also utilizes the time period and southern, New Orleans setting to mix in themes of racism, corruption, and consequences. I adore Mafia and Mafia II, but if they were every to make a film of one of these games, Mafia III has to be top for consideration. It is the most cinematic and well-written script.

It tells a story of revenge, of being a Veteran returning from Vietnam. It teaches about the corrupting nature of our actions, and how our actions (even those with good intentions) can have negative consequences for people we care about (Hollis Dupree trial, for example). It really captures the attitudes in the south in the 1960s U.S.

There are legitimate criticisms of the game, which I understand. The main one being the "repetitiveness" of the game's main mechanic, going from district to district, attacking rackets and taking them over. While I do see where this complaint comes from, I do not fully agree with the sentiment. This game and it's setting are so immersive, it did not affect me. I kept thinking that at some point, it would tire on me, but that moment never came.

Instead, I found New Bordeaux (New Orleans, 1960s) so immersive and fun, I wanted to squeeze out every possible second I could from the game. I just simply did not want it to end. I found taking each district, racket-by-racket, and choosing HOW I carved up New Orleans and WHO I gave control to for each district to be very, very fun.

Additionally, the inclusion of the three DLCs are fantastic and can be played interwoven at any point in the story once they become available. They are not too long, and they offer fantastic rewards (amazing vehicles, guns, abilities). The weed growing is fun and a great way to make additional money. The DLC stories themselves also deal with the overall game's narratives and themes in a way that serves to elevate them further.

The setting, music, atmosphere of this game is 10/10. 

I am from New Orleans, and I love seeing it depicted in video game media. It's such a unique and interesting city. So old, full of history, and so many cultures have immigrated to this city over the centuries, and all have left their mark on it. From Italians and Cajuns/Creole, to the Irish and Spanish. It's arguably the most unique city in the U.S., and this game does it justice. New Bordeaux and RDR2's St. Denis, gotta love them as great video game representations of NOLA.

All this to say, I highly recommend this game. It's emotional, introspective, full of fantastic characters with the voice actors giving their absolute all to every role in this game. I guarantee that if you sink yourself into this game and it's narrative, it will stick with you for a while afterwards.

After playing Mafia: The Old Country, a fourteen hour cutscene marathon pretending to be a Mafia game, Mafia 3 feels like stepping into an actual world again. And before I talk about how good Mafia 3 is, let me deal with a few of the unbelievably bad takes floating around Steam.

Calling Mafia 3 ‚ÄúGTA‚Äù because you can drive a car is ridiculous. Saying Lincoln has ‚Äúno charisma‚Äù just means you expected a Marvel quip machine instead of a serious character with weight and trauma. Crying about a GTX 1650 struggling in a big open-world game is not a Mafia 3 problem, that is your GPU waving a white flag. The people who claim they get 35 FPS on a 3080 or that the gameplay is ‚Äúatrocious‚Äù sound like they either played with settings from 2016 or were too confused to try stealth, guns, explosives, or anything besides running in a straight line. And the ‚Äúdata mining‚Äù panic is nothing more than standard analytics every modern publisher uses, but apparently Mafia 3 is where some players finally discovered the internet collects information.

Now that the nonsense is out of the way, let‚Äôs talk about the actual game, because this is where Mafia 3 absolutely shines. The story is fantastic and paced like someone who actually understands narrative structure. Lincoln Clay is one of the strongest, most believable characters in the entire franchise. The documentary-style storytelling adds tension, weight, and atmosphere in a way no other Mafia title has ever attempted.

The gameplay is where Mafia 3 truly pulls ahead. Combat is brutal, impactful, and fun every single time. Stealth works beautifully if you use it properly. Gunplay feels heavy and satisfying. Driving feels like real 1960s muscle instead of the loose toy-car feel some games go with. And the missions? Actually engaging. Actually structured. Actually worth doing. This is not a walking simulator like Old Country. This is a full criminal rise-to-power.

The world itself is alive and dripping with personality. Taking over rackets, assigning districts to lieutenants, deciding who you trust, and dismantling Marcano‚Äôs entire empire piece by piece creates a feeling of progression the series has never delivered at this scale. It feels like you are building something, not just watching events happen.

And performance? With a Ryzen 7 7800X3D and a Radeon 7900XTX, the game runs perfectly. Smooth, clean, no issues. Anyone claiming modern hardware cannot run it needs to troubleshoot their setup instead of reviewing the game.

Mafia 3 is not perfect, but it is stylish, violent, story-rich, and absolutely worth your time. Compared to the confused, rushed disappointment that was Old Country, this game feels like a full course meal. Mafia 3 does everything a Mafia game should do: immerse you, challenge you, and pull you into its world until you don‚Äôt want to leave.

If you think Mafia 3 lacks something, the issue is not the game.

The issue is you.

Mafia 3 is unexpectedly a decent enough game to try and beat. Since its release, it has not been favored among some Mafia fans, and it's viewed as the bottom of the three (probably better than Mafia 4 now, since its recent release). I'll say this: when I started playing the Mafia games, I knew of the warnings the fanbase had with this third installment, and I kept some low expectations from things like technical glitches in the game causing assets to not load properly, to downright crashes, all the way to the narrative of the story. I will say, there has been an effort made when making this third game. The world is humongous, attractive, and very interesting to explore in pretty much every aspect. Without spoiling much, one thing that took me off guard is the simple perspective that this does not feel like a traditional Mafia game. It's just me, but when I was thinking of Mafia games, I was thinking of the Italian New York and Chicago-like settings from the previous games, with more Italian mob family struggles. Having the story take place in a late 60s New Orleans southern setting with a PTSD infused Vietnam vet seeking revenge against racist white people is definitely new... It's pretty much a Vietnam Rambo Assassins Creed Hill-Billy Redneck slaughterfest simulator. It's not so much Italian but rather, as the game puts it, "Dixie". You are against the Dixie Mafia, essentially. There are elements that connect to other games that answer questions, but I wouldn't be surprised if it alienates the fedora-and-trenchcoat fans out there who were seeking something else. TL;DR: Mafia III tells one of the best stories in the series, with great characters, atmosphere, and music. It was once called repetitive, but on replay, it shows real depth through its world, missions, and design. The city is beautiful, the cars handle wonderfully, and for me, it rivals Mafia I in storytelling while finally giving Vito from Mafia II the justice he deserved.

When Mafia III released in 2016, it was ambitious, with a fresh setting, a new protagonist, and a deeper social backdrop. Set in New Bordeaux, a fictional version of New Orleans, the game replaced the classic mob romanticism of Mafia II with the raw and turbulent reality of 1960s America, filled with racial tension, political corruption, and the echoes of the Vietnam War. 

I remember everyone, including my younger self, saying the game was repetitive. And yes, some objectives repeat, but playing it again now, I see things differently. The game is well crafted, and even when the mission structure follows a pattern, the city itself keeps everything fresh. New Bordeaux is stunning, full of character and detail, with each district feeling alive, from the neon glow of the French Ward to the muddy backroads of the Bayou. The mission buildings have personality, the interiors are varied, and the atmosphere pulls you in every time.

Driving through the city feels fantastic. The cars have real weight, the handling is smooth but heavy in a satisfying way, and the period design makes every vehicle feel authentic. The sound of engines, the way the car slides through corners, and the look of the rain-soaked streets all make New Bordeaux a place worth exploring, not just a backdrop for missions.

To me, Mafia III rivals Mafia I when it comes to storytelling. I really like Lincoln Clay as a character, just as I liked Tommy Angelo. Both are grounded, human, and shaped by their choices and the people around them. The game also gives Vito from Mafia II a fitting continuation, finally showing him as the veteran mobster he was (maybe?) meant to become.

The cinematic presentation and soundtrack, featuring Hendrix, The Rolling Stones, Creedence Clearwater Revival, and many others, perfectly capture the mood of the era. The Definitive Edition from 2020 didn‚Äôt bring major changes beyond visuals and DLC integration, but it still holds up because of its powerful narrative, atmosphere, and attention to detail.

If you play Mafia III today, do it for the story, the city, and the experience of living through its world. It‚Äôs a game that grows on you, one that might have seemed repetitive at first, but with time, shows how carefully it was built and how much heart went into every part of it.
